Issues.Title: [release/9.0] Fix Color value in PageSettings
Issues.Body:
Backport of #13385 to release/9.0

/cc @JeremyKuhne

## Customer Impact
Reading `PageSettings.Color` gives the wrong value, there is no workaround.

## Testing
Regression unit test.

## Risk
Low, this was a manual mistake in converting to source generated interop.

 ###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://microsoft.github.io/open-pr/?codeflow=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/13389)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "[release/9.0] Fix Color value in PageSettings" (#13389)

Issues.Title: PrinterSettings.DefaultPageSettings.Color returns wrong value
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

9.0.0 and higher

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

Yes, tested on .NET 8.0.6 and .NET 8.0.15

### Issue description

When a new instance of PrinterSettings is created and the PrinterName is set, PrinterSettings.DefaultPageSettings.Color returns an incorrect value. The value appears to be negated.

``` c#
var printersettingsbw = new System.Drawing.Printing.PrinterSettings
{
    PrinterName = "[Name of B/W Printer]"
};

Console.WriteLine(printersettingsbw.DefaultPageSettings.Color); // returns true instead of false

var printersettingscolor = new System.Drawing.Printing.PrinterSettings
{
    PrinterName = "[Name of Color Printer]"
};

Console.WriteLine(printersettingscolor.DefaultPageSettings.Color); // returns false instead of true
```

### Steps to reproduce

1. Have a locally available color printer printer and b/w printer on your machine. If no printer available you can also use "Microsoft Print to PDF" for step 3.
2. Create new Instance of PrinterSettings
3. Set PrinterSettings.PrinterName with the name of you locally available printer. (or "Microsoft Print to PDF")
4. Get the PrinterSettings.DefaultPageSettings.Color value -> you get a wrong value (for "Microsoft Print to PDF" it should return Color = true but it returns Color = false)
5. Try the same steps in version below 9.0.0 -> you get the correct value.


Small testproject here:
[Testpoject.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/19889068/Testpoject.zip)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "PrinterSettings.DefaultPageSettings.Color returns wrong value" (#13367)

Issues.Title: Fix Color value in PageSettings
Issues.Body:
This was inadvertently flipped when changing to CsWin32. Moves helper code for using the PDF printer to write a regression test.

There is no practical workaround for this. If you're looking for whether a printer supports color, however, you can check `PrinterSettings.SupportsColor` instead. 

Fixes #13367

Issues.Title: [dnceng-bot] Branch `winforms/release/9.0` can't be merged to Azdo internal branch
Issues.Body:
Branch [release/9.0](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/commits/release/9.0/) in `dotnet/winforms` repo can't be mirrored from GitHub to Azure [internal/release/9.0](https://dev.azure.com/dnceng/internal/_git/dotnet-winforms?version=GBinternal%2Frelease%2F9.0&_a=history) via internal merge. 

There are conflicting commits in the target branch.
The branch is configured to be mirrored via automated merge. 
The situation is rare but normal. The target branch is expected to receive manual commits in the Azure DevOps clone, which could cause conflict.

Conflicts need to be **resolved to unblock the code flow**.

- you can resolve the issue by resolving the conflict in the **target branch only**. 
    - Please make sure that the changes sensitive from security perspective are not published ahead of time to GitHub!
- reverting the extra commits in the Azdo target branch.
- checking the logs of the mirroring process in the [mirroring pipeline](https://dev.azure.com/dnceng/internal/_build?definitionId=1387).
- you can disable the mirroring of the branch in the [configuration file](https://dev.azure.com/dnceng/internal/_git/dotnet-mirroring?path=/dnceng-subscriptions.jsonc).
- you can ask @dotnet/dnceng for help or read the [documentation](https://dev.azure.com/dnceng/internal/_git/dotnet-mirroring?path=/README.md).

Please close this issue once the conflict is resolved.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[dnceng-bot] Branch `winforms/release/9.0` can't be merged to Azdo internal branch" (#13386)

Issues.Title: Unable to build APPXUPLOAD from .NET 9.0 / C# / WinForms project
Issues.Body:
Hi!

We were advised by Microsoft Visual studio support to create this issue here. So, we hope that it is relevant to this repo. Please, let us know if not. The corresponding thread in DeveloperCommunity_VisualStudio can be found [here](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/t/Unable-to-build-APPXUPLOAD-from-NET-90/10892325).

---

###The essence

We’ve met this problem during the project (C#, WinForm) migration from `.NET Framework 4.8.1` to `.NET 9.0`.

***Steps to see the problem***:
1. We’ve migrated the project, compiled it and tested its functionality. Here we’ve found out that we are now required to publish the app with the `.pubxml` profile to make a single and not self-contained `.exe` instead of `.exe-.dll-.json-.json`… whatever this supposed to be.
2. Using the publishing profile we’ve obtained the single-file executable that we’ve tested on Win10-x64 and Win7-x86. Both tests have been passed. The installation of .NET 9.0.4 desktop redistributables is not the problem for our aims. It is even better to not to “take” it with the executable.
3. We’ve removed the .NET Framework project and added the .NET 9.0 project to the `.wapproj` dependencies without other changes. After this we get 3 warnings (fig. 1) about compatibility.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d015548d-42ea-4272-8690-e609a1888be1)

After that we can get two ***results***:

1. The builder can create a 100Mb bundle for 450Kb executable or (if single file option is enabled) 100Mb the-entire-OS-in-one-file executable. So, we literally can build package. But it will completely ruin the user (who downloads the app from Microsoft Store) experience. Not to mention that such an installation size is simply inadequate for the goals and objectives of the product.
2. With another project (we've tried it too) the builder can refuse to build the code during to non-existing errors (like missing ‘using’ directive). Exactly the same code has been successfully built during the publishing process 10 seconds ago.

Our thoughts: there is some problem in the `.wapproj` file and/or in the MSIX builder. Because all warnings and errors come from the step before zipping `.MSIX`s into `.appxbundle`.

---

***How to reproduce directly***:
1. Use this project to build a single-file-exe: [TestProject_NET9.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/19913854/TestProject_NET9.zip). This is the partial copy of our actual product without our own sensitive assemblies. It’s free for testing (available on GitHub).
2. Add the new WAP project (MSIX/APPX packaging project), connect the .NET 9.0 project to it. We can only provide our sample of `.wapproj`, without certificates and thumbprints, just to check its properties and verify its integrity: [ScreenShooter_MSIX.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/19913870/ScreenShooter_MSIX.zip).
3. Try to publish the bundle.

---

***Tried workarounds***:
- Creating new `.wapproj`: no effect
- Clearing all building directories and caches: no effect
- Updating NuGets: no effect

---

***Other notes***:
Also when builder tries to do its work we can see about 900 warnings about possible compatibility problems for basic methods from `System`, `System.Windows.Forms` and other assemblies.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/e8c90dc3-39c6-49de-af7a-1bff23508138)

So, now we can still publish Android apps, APKs, Windows MSI packages, EXEs. But we cannot build apps for Microsoft Store. Which is not funny at all.

---

So, how can we fix it? We’ve lost 6 hours in search. But found nothing useful.

Thank you in advance,
RD AAOW FDL

Issues.Title: ToolStripComboBox in ContextMenuStrip displays incorrectly when RightToLeft is set to Yes on parent control
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.NET 10.0.100-preview.5.25223.16

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

No

### Issue description

**Current behavior**

When RightToLeft is set to Yes on the Button, right-clicking it causes the ToolStripComboBox inside the ContextMenuStrip to display incorrectly. The text appears misaligned or clipped, and the dropdown arrow is partially hidden or shifted out of view.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/72f36072-e4ef-47b9-9280-21659acd76d6)

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/008f34bc-990f-484f-9c19-d8a5f1f762f6

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a new WinForms .NET Core project.
2. Add a Button, a PropertyGrid, and a ContextMenuStrip to the form.
3. Add a ToolStripComboBox to the ContextMenuStrip and assign the ContextMenuStrip to the Button.
4. In the Button’s Click event handler, set propertyGrid1.SelectedObject = button1;.
5. Run the application and right-click the Button to open the ContextMenuStrip.
6. Select any item from the ToolStripComboBox and it should display and function correctly.
7. While the application is running, set the Button’s RightToLeft property to Yes using the PropertyGrid.
8. Right-click the Button again and observe the rendering of the ToolStripComboBox.

or
Download, unzip, and run this sample project to test the issue
[WinFormsApp3.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/19886607/WinFormsApp3.zip)

### More Info

1. The issue does not occur when the RightToLeft property is set via the designer before running the application.
2. The issue can be reproduced with other controls that support binding to a ContextMenuStrip.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "ToolStripComboBox in ContextMenuStrip displays incorrectly when RightToLeft is set to Yes on parent control" (#13365)

Issues.Title: Add Framework folder from multitarget repository to the new multi-target version of DemoConsole
Issues.Body:
Fixes #13372

## Proposed changes

- Add Framework folder from https://github.com/JeremyKuhne/multitarget to the new multi-target version of `DemoConsole`.
- Adapts namespaces in order to avoid type collisions with assemblies from other target frameworks.

## Customer Impact

- Hints on how to add compatibility files to versions of .NET that might require it (In this case, `net472`, as in the [multitarget repository](https://github.com/JeremyKuhne/multitarget)).

## Regression?

- No

## Risk

- Minimal

## Test methodology

- Manual

## Test environment(s)

- 10.0.100-preview.3.25201.16

 ###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://microsoft.github.io/open-pr/?codeflow=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/13373)

Issues.Title: Changing the position of the BindingSource triggers the ListChanged event with ListChangedType.ItemAdded
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

8.0

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

No

### Issue description

We are currently using a BindingSource as the data source for a DataGridView, and have observed the following behavior:

When a new row is added to the BindingSource using the AddNew() method, the ListChanged event is triggered with ListChangedType.ItemAdded, which is expected behavior.

However, if we subsequently change the position of the BindingSource (e.g., navigate to another row), the ListChanged event is triggered again with ListChangedType.ItemAdded, even though no additional rows are explicitly added.



### Steps to reproduce

1. Run the Sample
2. From the rows available in the table, select a row 
3. Now click the duplicate button 

Observed behavior - The ListChanged event with ListChangedType.ItemAdded is triggered when the position of the BindingSource is changed.
Expected behavior - Changing the position should not trigger the ListChanged event with ListChangedType.ItemAdded.

Sample:
[MSDataGrid_Demo.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/19890192/MSDataGrid_Demo.zip)


Demo Video:

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/f2d09bd5-8543-4e3d-b045-6b5838d6d73f



In the demo, the first message box was shown when the ListChanged event was triggered by AddNew(). After adding the row, when I changed the position of the BindingSource, the ListChanged event was triggered again with ListChangedType.ItemAdded, resulting in the display of a second message box.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Changing the position of the BindingSource triggers the ListChanged event with ListChangedType.ItemAdded" (#13369)

Issues.Title: Visual Studio is Interactable and Becomes Unresponsive When Displaying a Custom Form via UITypeEditor using ShowDialog() in a .NET Core Client-Server approach
Issues.Body:
### Environment

Microsoft Visual Studio Professional 2022 (64-bit) - Current
Version 17.13.6

### .NET version

.NET80 and .NET90

### Did this work in a previous version of Visual Studio and/or previous .NET release?

_No response_

### Issue description

When displaying a custom form for the UITypeEditor using ShowDialog() within the server project of a client-server approach, the form is successfully shown but fails to prevent interaction with Visual Studio. Consequently, Visual Studio becomes unresponsive until the form is closed, at which point responsiveness is restored. This issue is specific to .NET Core and does not occur in .NET Framework.

**Code to show the form:**
```
 internal class CustomEditorFormHandler : RequestHandler<CustomEditorFormEndpoint.Request, CustomEditorFormEndpoint.Response>
 {
     public override CustomEditorFormEndpoint.Response HandleRequest(CustomEditorFormEndpoint.Request request)
     {
         CustomControl customControl = (CustomControl)request.CustomControl;
         new CustomEditorForm().ShowDialog();
         return new CustomEditorFormEndpoint.Response();
     }
 }
```

We would appreciate any guidance or suggestions on resolving this issue, particularly in restricting interactions with Visual Studio and addressing the unresponsiveness.

**Demo sample:**

[CustomControlLibrary_WithSample.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/19886388/CustomControlLibrary_WithSample.zip)

**Issue replication video:**

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/02791544-e04b-4d3d-9ce6-b31247212c85


### Steps to reproduce

1. Open the Designer.
2. Click on the CustomControl and open the Properties window.
3. Open the custom form of the "MyCollection" property (via UITypeEditor).
4. Click randomly within Visual Studio.

**Expected Behavior:**
Visual Studio should not be interactable and should not become unresponsive, like the .NET Framework.

**Observed Behavior:**
Visual Studio remains interactable and becomes unresponsive.

### Diagnostics

```text

```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Visual Studio is Interactable and Becomes Unresponsive When Displaying a Custom Form via UITypeEditor using ShowDialog() in a .NET Core Client-Server approach" (#13366)
